AttributeReference.description: Relative endpoint address on which the ESB Bus listens to the incoming request, for example "/payment"

AttributeReference.ErrorMessage: Enter a valid URL. E.g. /wsdl/sample.wsdl; wsdl/sample.wsdl
AttributeReference.description: URL to the WSDL defining the WS provider endpoint. URL format: wsdl/<InterfaceName>.wsdl, where the WSDL is available in src.main.resources.wsdl
Name of the selected service contained in the referenced WSDL
Name of the selected Endpoint of a selected service (that you provide in the Service Name field) contained in the referenced WSDL
Standard: Message is executed with standard processing mechanism. Robust: Provider invokes service synchronously and the processing errors are returned to the consumer.
Via Manual Configuration in Channel: Define the WS-Security settings manually. None: No WS-Security configuration.
Specify if the incoming message is signed or signed and encrypted.
Stores the incoming signed (and encrypted) message.
WS-Consumer has to send a time stamp along with the message. In case of a request-response pattern, a time stamp is added to the response message.
Specify the alias for the private key that is to be used to sign the response message.
Specify the alias for the public key that is to be used to encrypt the response message.
Initiator Token section defines policies for the WS-Consumer. AlwaysToRecipient ensures that the WS-Consumer sends the certificate along with the message.
Initiator Token section defines policies for the WS-Consumer. X509 Token Assertion defines the format of the certificate being sent by the WS-Consumer along with the message.
Recipient Token section defines policies for the WS-Consumer. AlwaysToInitiator adds the certificate to the response message.
Relative endpoint address on which the ESB Bus listens to the incoming request, for example "/payment"

AttributeReference.ErrorMessage: Enter a valid URL. E.g. /wsdl/sample.wsdl; wsdl/sample.wsdl
AttributeReference.description: URL to the WSDL defining the WS provider endpoint. URL format: wsdl/<InterfaceName>.wsdl, where the WSDL is available in src.main.resources.wsdl
Used for reliable one-way message exchanges. The consumer sends a message to a provider, which returns a status. When the processing fails a fault is returned.

AttributeReference.ErrorMessage: Enter a valid address. E.g. http(s)://example
AttributeReference.description: Endpoint address on which the ESB Bus posts the outgoing message, for example "https://host:port/payment"
Specify the proxy type to be used.

AttributeReference.ErrorMessage: Enter a valid URL. E.g. /wsdl/sample.wsdl; wsdl/sample.wsdl
AttributeReference.description: URL to the WSDL defining the WS provider endpoint. URL format: wsdl/<InterfaceName>.wsdl, where the WSDL is available in src.main.resources.wsdl
Name of the selected service contained in the referenced WSDL
Name of the selected Endpoint of a selected service (that you provide in the Service Name field) contained in the referenced WSDL
Name of the operation for selected service contained in the referenced WSDL

AttributeReference.ErrorMessage: Enter a valid number of milliseconds (digits only)
AttributeReference.description: Specifies the amount of time, in milliseconds, that the client will wait for a response before it times out: 0 specifies that the client will wait indefinitely
Enable this WS endpoint to: Send compressed request messages to WS Provider Indicate to WS Provider that it can handle compressed response messages
Select this option to allow HTTP Chunking of data while sending messages
Select this option if your server allows connections without authentication at the transport level
Select this option to allow the ESB bus to connect to the receiver system using the deployed basic authentication credentials
Enter the credential name of the username-password pair specified during the deployment of basic authentication credentials on the tenant
Enter an alias to identify the private key to communicate with a receiver using HTTPs protocol.
Via Manual Configuration in Channel: Define the WS-Security settings manually. Based on Policies in WSDL: WS-Security configuration is specified in WSDL.

Select an option for authentication on message level. Plain Text Password: The Password is transfered in plain text (https-encrypted). Hashed Password (Password Digest): Cryptographic hash function is applied for password.
Enter the credential name, that is, the alias that was assigned to the authorized user and password during tenant deployment
Enter the credential name, that is, the alias that was assigned to the authorized user and password during tenant deployment
Choose to sign or sign and encrypt the outgoing message.
Sending a time stamp along with the message. In case of a request-response pattern, a time stamp is expected in the response message.
Specify the alias for the private key that is to be used to sign the message.
Specify the alias for the public key that is to be used to encrypt the message.
Specify a private key alias that is used to sign the message.
Specify a public key alias that is used to encrypt the message.
Initiator Token section defines policies for the WS-Consumer. AlwaysToRecipient will add the certificate to the message.
Initiator Token section defines policies for the WS-Consumer. X509 Token Assertion defines the format of the certificate being sent along with the message.
Recipient Token section defines policies for the WS-Consumer. AlwaysToInitiator expects the recipient to send the certificate along with the response message.
Initiator Token section defines policies for the WS-Consumer. X509 Token Assertion defines the format of the certificate being sent along with the message.

Strict: Select this option to check that a SOAP message adheres to the WS-Policy strict layout rules. Lax: Select this option to ensure that the security token in the SOAP header has been inserted according to the Lax WS-Policy layout rules.
